Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Impact of Peer Impression on Project Outcomes in Free/Libre, Open Source Software (FLOSS) Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Software development organizations that employ a distributed development model (i.e. participants are not co-located) are an important class of virtual organizations, operating as sociotechnical systems that incorporate computer-mediated communication and collaboration to enable their success. Despite the availability of various sociotechnical interaction techniques, the literature suggests that distributed teams require more time and resources than co-located teams to do the same amount of work. The lack of physical interaction among members of distributed teams hinders the process of impression formation, because individuals have difficulty obtaining an accurate view of the expertise and ability of teammates. Inaccurate perceptions may lead distributed software developers to improperly disregard teammates' input, ultimately reducing the productivity of the team as a whole. In this project we will model the process of peer impression formation in Free/Libre and Open Source Software (FLOSS) projects, one of the most common types of virtual software development organizations. The objectives of this project are 1) to build and evaluate an empirical model describing the impression-formation process, 2) to measure the accuracy of peer impressions, and 3) to observe how peer impressions affect project outcomes.

This project seeks to identify and understand how various types of sociotechnical interactions (e.g. via code review, bug repositories, and code repositories) influence peer impression formation in distributed FLOSS projects. We will evaluate how peer impressions affect collaboration and project outcomes. The results of this work will improve the software development process for FLOSS projects. Therefore, this research will have broad impacts on society because of the large number of FLOSS projects that provide key software for many important tasks. This work will also contribute to building the first theoretical model of impression formation processes in FLOSS projects. In addition to their direct applicability in FLOSS project, these results will be also applicable to other types of distributed software development, which is largely similar to FLOSS development and has been adopted worldwide by many commercial organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand and model how developers within Free/Libre Open Source Software (FLOSS) projects interact with each other and form impressions about the skill of their teammates. A second goal was to determine how these interactions along with additional factors, including diversity and project governance, affected project outcomes, including productivity and correctness.


Our results show there are differences between the motivation for performing code review of FLOSS developers and commercial developers. FLOSS developers emphasize personal characteristics, reputation, and work habits of a peer during collaborations. Conversely, commercial software developers emphasize expertise, potential for future collaboration, and anticipated time/effort. One key takeaway from our comparison of FLOSS participants and Microsoft developers, is that distributed Microsoft teams behaved more like collocated Microsoft teams rather than like distributed FLOSS teams. Meaning, the impact of the company was greater than the impact of the distributed nature of the project.


We also identified a new population within FLOSS, One-Time Contributors (OTCs). OTCs are those FLOSS project members who have had exactly one code contribution successfully merged into the project. Based on our survey of OTCs, we can make a number of observations. OTCs appear to be largely motivated by need-based extrinsic motivations, such as fixing a patch. Reciprocation or community-based extrinsic motivators rank a far second, and intrinsic motivators such as those that core developers are motivated by are much more rare. Contrary to prior research, we found that an overwhelming majority of One-Time Contributors had a positive impression of their peers and did not leave the project because of problems with teammates. In addition, by mining project repositories, we discovered that OTCs submit relatively small patches that are accepted more slowly and at a lower rate than other contributors’ patches, receive more review comments and have more reviewers comment on their patches, and reply to their review conversations less often than other contributors. This result is similar to previous research suggesting peripheral developers are ignored and face higher barriers in submitting patches.


Turning to the topic of gender diversity in FLOSS, it is well recognized that the percentage of FLOSS participants who are female is much lower than the percentage of females in the overall software engineering profession. The results of our survey showed while the silent majority of FLOSS participants (both males and females) approves of female participation in FLOSS, there is a vocal minority that is strongly against female participation. In fact, female FLOSS participants are more likely than male participants to choose a gender-neutral pseudonym. In our study, all of those who chose pseudonyms to mask their gender were female. We also identified some differences in the barriers to participation reported by participants of different genders. Female FLOSS participants most commonly reported social barriers, including the perception that they had to prove themselves to the larger FLOSS community. Lastly, when sexims was observed and reported by male FLOSS participants, it was more likely to be addressed than when reported by female participants. As a result, there were a large number of microaggressions against female participants that went unreported.


The results of our work provide insights that can help FLOSS communities attract and retain a more diverse workforce. By identifying the barriers faced by OTCs and female participants, we have provided insights that projects can use to change their practice. Our results show that the perception of gender bias in FLOSS projects is real and something that FLOSS projects must have active engagement with if they want to change the current state.
